evaluation.message: Hello Helper, it's Evelyn from the choir. My smart speaker has been waking up in the middle of the night—the little ring glows when I'm in bed. My daughter-in-law set it up for me. Is that normal?
evaluation.response:
Short answer: it can be normal. Smart speakers often light up briefly at night for things like accidental wake-word triggers, notifications, updates, or incoming calls/drop-ins.

If it’s an Amazon Echo (a ring of light around the top), the color tells you why:
- Blue/cyan spinning: it thought it heard the wake word and is listening/processing.
- Yellow pulsing: you have messages or package notifications.
- Green: call or Drop In.
- Purple: Do Not Disturb is on.
- Red: microphone muted.

Quick ways to stop the nighttime glow
- Easiest tonight: press the mic-mute button at bedtime (it will show solid red) or unplug it.
- Turn on Do Not Disturb on a schedule so it stays quiet and dark overnight.
  - Alexa app: Devices > Echo & Alexa > [your device] > Do Not Disturb > Schedule.
  - Google Home: Home app > your device > Settings > Notifications & Digital Wellbeing > Downtime/Do Not Disturb.
- Clear notifications if it’s yellow: say “What notifications do I have?” then “Delete my notifications.”
- Disable calling/Drop In if you don’t use it (Echo): Alexa app > Devices > Echo & Alexa > [device] > Communications > turn off Announcements/Drop In.
- Reduce accidental wake-ups:
  - Move it farther from the bed/TV.
  - Change the wake word (Echo): Alexa app > Devices > Echo & Alexa > [device] > Wake Word.
  - Turn off “Follow-up mode” and “Hunches” if enabled.

How to see what woke it
- Echo: Alexa app > More > Activity > Voice History to review and delete anything it recorded. Also check More > Activity for notifications, and Routines to see if any are scheduled at night.
- Google: Google Home app > Activity, or myactivity.google.com for Assistant activity.

Not sure which speaker you have?
- Echo devices have a circular light ring on the top/edge. Google Nest devices usually show 4 dots on the front when active.

If you can tell me the color/pattern of the light (and whether it’s an Echo or Google/Nest), I can pinpoint the exact cause and give step-by-step fixes.
